5641.text: It clenches opponents with its left arm and finishes them off with foul-smelling poison gas belched from its mouth.

5642.text: Consuming garbage makes new kinds of poison gases and liquids inside their bodies.

5643.text: Beware the poisonous liquid it shoots from its right arm. If even a little of it gets on you, you’ll experience the effects of the unidentified toxin.

5644.text: For a time, their numbers increased explosively in Alola. Since the arrival of Grimer, their population has decreased dramatically.

5645.text: It locks opponents in place with its left hand, immobilizing them by entirely dousing their bodies with poisonous liquid.

5646.text: Some say the reason Garbodor in Alola are a little stronger than their counterparts elsewhere is the presence of Muk, their natural enemy.

5647.text: This Pokémon eats trash, which turns into poison inside its body. The main component of the poison depends on what sort of trash was eaten.

5648.text: The toxic liquid it launches from its right arm is so virulent that it can kill a weakened creature instantly.

5649.text: It changes into the forms of others to surprise them. Apparently, it often transforms into a silent child.

5650.text: It changes so it looks just like its foe, tricks it, and then uses that opportunity to flee.

5651.text: To protect themselves from danger, they hide their true identities by transforming into people and Pokémon.

5652.text: This Pokémon has a cowardly disposition, so when it’s not around friends, it basically always stays transformed as something else.

5653.text: If a normally talkative child suddenly stops talking, it may have been replaced by Zorua.

5654.text: Zorua is a timid Pokémon. This disposition seems to be what led to the development of Zorua’s ability to take on the forms of other creatures.

5655.text: Zorua sometimes transforms into a person and goes into cities to search for food. When Zorua does this, it usually takes on the form of a child.

5656.text: A once-departed soul, returned to life in Hisui. Derives power from resentment, which rises as energy atop its head and takes on the forms of foes. In this way, Zorua vents lingering malice.

5657.text: Stories say those who tried to catch Zoroark were trapped in an illusion and punished.

5658.text: Each has the ability to fool a large group of people simultaneously. They protect their lair with illusory scenery.

5659.text: Bonds between these Pokémon are very strong. It protects the safety of its pack by tricking its opponents.

5660.text: It doesn’t just transform itself—it also has the power to make hundreds of people see its illusions.

5661.text: If it thinks humans are going to discover its den, Zoroark shows them visions that make them wander around in the woods.

5662.text: This Pokémon cares deeply about others of its kind, and it will conjure terrifying illusions to keep its den and pack safe.

5663.text: Seeking to ease the burden of their solitude, lonely Trainers tell Zoroark to show illusions to them.

5664.text: With its disheveled white fur, it looks like an embodiment of death. Heedless of its own safety, Zoroark attacks its nemeses with a bitter energy so intense, it lacerates Zoroark's own body.

5665.text: They greet one another by rubbing each other with their tails, which are always kept well groomed and clean.

5666.text: Minccino greet each other by grooming one another thoroughly with their tails.

5667.text: These Pokémon prefer a tidy habitat. They are always sweeping and dusting, using their tails as brooms.

5668.text: A clean freak that will not allow even the slightest mess, it uses its tail like a mop to thoroughly clean any and all filth.

5669.text: When its tail has gotten dirty from self-cleaning or from cleaning its nest, Minccino spends a whole day washing its tail in clean spring water.

5670.text: The way it brushes away grime with its tail can be helpful when cleaning. But its focus on spotlessness can make cleaning more of a hassle.

5671.text: They pet each other with their tails as a form of greeting. Of the two, the one whose tail is fluffier is a bit more boastful.

5672.text: Their white fur is coated in a special oil that makes it easy for them to deflect attacks.

5673.text: Their white fur feels amazing to touch. Their fur repels dust and prevents static electricity from building up.

5674.text: Cinccino’s body is coated in a special oil that helps it deflect attacks, such as punches.

5675.text: The white parts of its coat are covered in an oil secreted from its body, so this Pokémon can slide right away from its enemies’ attacks.

5676.text: The oil that seeps from its body is really smooth. For people troubled by bad skin, this oil is an effective treatment.

5677.text: Its body secretes oil that this Pokémon spreads over its nest as a coating to protect it from dust. Cinccino won’t tolerate even a speck of the stuff.

5678.text: A special oil that seeps through their fur helps them avoid attacks. The oil fetches a high price at market.

5679.text: It stares intently at everything. It can become so obsessed with watching that it doesn’t notice attacks.

5680.text: Their ribbonlike feelers increase their psychic power. They are always staring at something.

5681.text: They intently observe both Trainers and Pokémon. Apparently, they are looking at something that only Gothita can see.

5682.text: Though they’re still only babies, there’s psychic power stored in their ribbonlike feelers, and sometimes they use that power to fight.

5683.text: Even when nobody seems to be around, Gothita can still be heard making a muted cry. Many believe it’s speaking to something only it can see.

5684.text: They use hypnosis to control people and Pokémon. Tales of Gothorita leading people astray are told in every corner.

5685.text: Starlight is the source of their power. At night, they mark star positions by using psychic power to float stones.

5686.text: According to many old tales, it creates friends for itself by controlling sleeping children on starry nights.

5687.text: It’s said that when stars shine in the night sky, this Pokémon will spirit away sleeping children. Some call it the Witch of Punishment.

5688.text: On nights when the stars shine, this Pokémon’s psychic power is at its strongest. It’s unknown just what link Gothorita has to the greater universe.

5689.text: It can see the future from the movement of the stars. When it learns its Trainer’s life span, it cries in sadness.

5690.text: Starry skies thousands of light-years away are visible in the space distorted by their intense psychic power.

5691.text: They can predict the future from the placement and movement of the stars. They can see Trainers’ life spans.

5692.text: It has tremendous psychic power, but it dislikes conflict. It’s also able to predict the future based on the movement of the stars.

5693.text: A criminal who was shown his fate by a Gothitelle went missing that same day and was never seen again.

5694.text: Because their bodies are enveloped in a special liquid, they can survive in any environment.

5695.text: Because their bodies are enveloped in a special liquid, they are fine in any environment, no matter how severe.

5696.text: They drive away attackers by unleashing psychic power. They can use telepathy to talk with others.

5697.text: It communicates with others telepathically. Its body is encapsulated in liquid, but if it takes a heavy blow, the liquid will leak out.

5698.text: Many say that the special liquid covering this Pokémon’s body would allow it to survive in the vacuum of space.

5699.text: When their brains, now divided in two, are thinking the same thoughts, these Pokémon exhibit their maximum power.

5700.text: Since they have two divided brains, at times they suddenly try to take two different actions at once.

5701.text: When their two divided brains think the same thoughts, their psychic power is maximized.

5702.text: Its psychic power can supposedly cover a range of more than half a mile—but only if its two brains can agree with each other.

5703.text: Its brain has split into two, and the two halves rarely think alike. Its actions are utterly unpredictable.

5704.text: These remarkably intelligent Pokémon fight by controlling arms that can grip with rock-crushing power.

5705.text: They use psychic power to control their arms, which are made of a special liquid. They can crush boulders psychically.

5706.text: When Reuniclus shake hands, a network forms between their brains, increasing their psychic power.

5707.text: While it could use its psychic abilities in battle, this Pokémon prefers to swing its powerful arms around to beat opponents into submission.

5708.text: It’s said that drinking the liquid surrounding Reuniclus grants wisdom. Problem is, the liquid is highly toxic to anything besides Reuniclus itself.

5709.text: These bird Pokémon are excellent divers. They swim around in the water eating their favorite food--peat moss.

5710.text: When attacked, it uses its feathers to splash water, escaping under cover of the spray.

5711.text: They are better at swimming than flying, and they happily eat their favorite food, peat moss, as they dive underwater.

5712.text: It administers sharp, powerful pecks with its bill. It whips its long neck to deliver forceful repeated strikes.

5713.text: Despite their elegant appearance, they can flap their wings strongly and fly for thousands of miles.

5714.text: Swanna start to dance at dusk. The one dancing in the middle is the leader of the flock.

5715.text: Theoretically, this Pokémon formed from icicles bathed in energy from the morning sun. Their breath is -58° F.

5716.text: The temperature of their breath is -58 degrees Fahrenheit. They create snow crystals and make snow fall in the areas around them.

5717.text: This Pokémon formed from icicles bathed in energy from the morning sun. It sleeps buried in snow.

5718.text: Born of an icicle, this Pokémon uses its frosty breath to make ice crystals, causing snow to fall.

5719.text: It feels pleasantly cool when embraced. This Pokémon is treasured by households in warm regions.

5720.text: It exhales cold air that is at –58 degrees Fahrenheit. When it’s in a warm place, it shrinks little by little.

5721.text: When the morning sun hit an icicle, it wished not to melt, and thus Vanillite was born. At night, it buries itself in snow to sleep.

5722.text: Unable to survive in hot areas, it makes itself comfortable by breathing out air cold enough to cause snow. It burrows into the snow to sleep.

5723.text: Supposedly, this Pokémon was born from an icicle. It spews out freezing air at −58 degrees Fahrenheit to make itself more comfortable.

5724.text: It conceals itself from enemy eyes by creating many small ice particles and hiding among them.

5725.text: They cool down the surrounding air and create ice particles, which they use to freeze their foes.

5726.text: Snowy mountains are this Pokémon’s habitat. During an ancient ice age, they moved to southern areas.

5727.text: Hot days cause its body to melt. It can be restored by refreezing it, but the process leaves its body slightly warped.

5728.text: This Pokémon has existed since the Ice Age. It controls particles of ice, freezes its opponents, and then shatters them with a headbutt.

5729.text: It sprays its enemies with grains of ice to freeze them. Most Vanillish in Alola are smaller than average.

5730.text: This hearty Pokémon survived the Ice Age. It’s incredibly popular in very hot regions.

5731.text: By drinking pure water, it grows its icy body. This Pokémon can be hard to find on days with warm, sunny weather.

5732.text: It blasts enemies with cold air reaching −148 degrees Fahrenheit, freezing them solid. But it spares their lives afterward—it’s a kind Pokémon.

5733.text: If both heads get angry simultaneously, this Pokémon expels a blizzard, burying everything in snow.

5734.text: Swallowing large amounts of water, they make snow clouds inside their bodies and, when angry, cause violent blizzards.

5735.text: Each of its two heads has a brain, and when they are in agreement, it attacks its enemies by exhaling a violent blizzard.

5736.text: Even if it loses one of its heads, it can live relatively problem-free. It makes snow clouds inside its body.

5737.text: It blasts blizzards from its two mouths. It can create snow anywhere, so it gets a lot of love from skiers and snowboarders.

5738.text: Vanilluxe is born when two Vanillish, half-melted by the day’s light, stick to each other and freeze together in the cold return of night.

5739.text: When its anger reaches a breaking point, this Pokémon unleashes a fierce blizzard that freezes every creature around it, be they friend or foe.

5740.text: People believe this Pokémon formed when two Vanillish stuck together. Its body temperature is roughly 21 degrees Fahrenheit.

5741.text: The color and scent of their fur changes to match the mountain grass. When they sense hostility, they hide in the grass.

5742.text: Their coloring changes according to the seasons and can be slightly affected by the temperature and humidity as well.

5743.text: The turning of the seasons changes the color and scent of this Pokémon’s fur. People use it to mark the seasons.

5744.text: The plants growing on its horns change according to the season. The leaders of the herd possess magnificent horns.

5745.text: They migrate according to the seasons. People can tell the season by looking at Sawsbuck’s horns.

5746.text: They migrate according to the seasons, so some people call Sawsbuck the harbingers of spring.

5747.text: It glides on its outstretched membrane while shocking foes with the electricity stored in the pouches on its cheeks.

5748.text: They live on treetops and glide using the inside of a cape-like membrane while discharging electricity.

5749.text: The energy made in its cheeks’ electric pouches is stored inside its membrane and released while it is gliding.

5750.text: It glides using its cape-like membrane. Electrical energy scatters from it, shocking its friends and foes alike.

5751.text: It grills berries and bug Pokémon with electric shocks and makes a meal of them. It usually nests in the holes gouged in trees by Pikipek.

5752.text: They store up electricity to fly through the air. When thunder cracks at night, sometimes there are almost enough of them to blot out the sky.

5753.text: As it flies, it scatters electricity around, so bird Pokémon keep their distance. That’s why Emolga can keep all its food to itself.

5754.text: As Emolga flutters through the air, it crackles with electricity. This Pokémon is cute, but it can cause a lot of trouble.

5755.text: This Pokémon absolutely loves sweet berries. Sometimes it stuffs its cheeks full of so much food that it can’t fly properly.

5756.text: When they feel threatened, they spit an acidic liquid to drive attackers away. This Pokémon targets Shelmet.

5757.text: These mysterious Pokémon evolve when they receive electrical stimulation while they are in the same place as Shelmet.

5758.text: For some reason they evolve when they receive electrical energy while they are attacking Shelmet.

5759.text: Its strange physiology reacts to electrical energy in interesting ways. The presence of a Shelmet will cause this Pokémon to evolve.

5760.text: It spits a liquid from its mouth to melt through Shelmet’s shell. Karrablast doesn’t eat the shell— it eats only the contents.

5761.text: They fly around at high speed, striking with their pointed spears. Even when in trouble, they face opponents bravely.

5762.text: Wearing the shell covering they stole from Shelmet, they defend themselves and attack with two lances.

5763.text: These Pokémon evolve by wearing the shell covering of a Shelmet. The steel armor protects their whole body.

5764.text: They use shells they’ve stolen from Shelmet to arm and protect themselves. They’re very popular Pokémon in the Galar region.

5765.text: It charges its enemies, lances at the ready. An image of one of its duels is captured in a famous painting of Escavalier clashing with Sirfetch’d.

5766.text: For some reason, this Pokémon resembles a Poké Ball. They release poison spores to repel those who try to catch them.

5767.text: It lures people in with its Poké Ball pattern, then releases poison spores. Why it resembles a Poké Ball is unknown.

5768.text: It lures Pokémon with its pattern that looks just like a Poké Ball, then releases poison spores.

5769.text: No one knows what the Poké Ball–like pattern on Foongus means or why Foongus has it.

5770.text: The spores released from this Pokémon’s hands are highly poisonous, but when thoroughly dried, the spores can be used as stomach medicine.

5771.text: It moves the caps on both arms and does a dance to lure prey. It prefers damp places.

5772.text: They show off their Poké Ball caps to lure prey, but very few Pokémon are fooled by this.

5773.text: It lures prey close by dancing and waving its arm caps, which resemble Poké Balls, in a swaying motion.

5774.text: This Pokémon puffs poisonous spores at its foes. If the spores aren’t washed off quickly, they’ll grow into mushrooms wherever they land.

5775.text: Amoonguss generally doesn’t move much. It tends to stand still near Poké Balls that have been dropped on the ground.

5776.text: With its thin, veil-like arms wrapped around the body of its opponent, it sinks to the ocean floor.

5777.text: They paralyze prey with poison, then drag them down to their lairs, five miles below the surface.

5778.text: If its veil-like arms stun and wrap a foe, that foe will be dragged miles below the surface, never to return.

5779.text: It wraps its veillike arms and legs around prey swimming by and drags them down to the depths of the ocean.

5780.text: Using the invisible poison spikes on its veillike arms and legs, it paralyzes its enemies and causes them to drown.

5781.text: It envelops its prey in its veillike arms and draws it down to the deeps, five miles below the ocean’s surface.

5782.text: Legend has it that the residents of a sunken ancient city changed into these Pokémon.

5783.text: They propel themselves by expelling absorbed seawater from their bodies. Their favorite food is life energy.

5784.text: Its body is mostly seawater. It’s said there’s a castle of ships Jellicent have sunk on the seafloor.

5785.text: The fate of the ships and crew that wander into Jellicent’s habitat: all sunken, all lost, all vanished.

5786.text: Jellicent is always hanging around fancy cruise ships and tankers, hoping to drag away its prey.

5787.text: Fishermen are terrified of Jellicent. It’s rumored to drag them into the sea and steal their lives away.

5788.text: Most of this Pokémon’s body composition is identical to sea water. It makes sunken ships its lair.

5789.text: Whenever a full moon hangs in the night sky, schools of Jellicent gather near the surface of the sea, waiting for their prey to appear.

5790.text: The special membrane enveloping Alomomola has the ability to heal wounds.

5791.text: Floating in the open sea is how they live. When they find a wounded Pokémon, they embrace it and bring it to shore.

5792.text: It gently holds injured and weak Pokémon in its fins. Its special membrane heals their wounds.

5793.text: It uses its special mucus to close the wounds of injured Pokémon. The reason for this behavior remains unknown.

5794.text: They float upon the open sea. Many water Pokémon gather in the area around Alomomola.

5795.text: Fishermen take them along on long voyages, because if you have an Alomomola with you, there’ll be no need for a doctor or medicine.

5796.text: The reason it helps Pokémon in a weakened condition is that any Pokémon coming after them may also attack Alomomola.

5797.text: Joltik that live in cities have learned a technique for sucking electricity from the outlets in houses.

5798.text: Since it can’t generate its own electricity, it sticks onto large-bodied Pokémon and absorbs static electricity.

5799.text: They attach themselves to large-bodied Pokémon and absorb static electricity, which they store in an electric pouch.

5800.text: Joltik can be found clinging to other Pokémon. It’s soaking up static electricity because it can’t produce a charge on its own.

5801.text: Joltik latch on to other Pokémon and suck out static electricity. They’re often found sticking to Yamper’s hindquarters.

5802.text: It creates barriers from electrified silk that stun foes. This works as a weapon as well as a defense.

5803.text: They employ an electrically charged web to trap their prey. While it is immobilized by shock, they leisurely consume it.

5804.text: When attacked, they create an electric barrier by spitting out many electrically charged threads.

5805.text: It launches electrified fur from its abdomen as its means of attack. Opponents hit by the fur could be in for three full days and nights of paralysis.

5806.text: It lays traps of electrified threads near the nests of bird Pokémon, aiming to snare chicks that are not yet good at flying.

5807.text: They stick their spikes into cave walls and absorb the minerals they find in the rock.

5808.text: When threatened, it attacks by shooting a barrage of spikes, which gives it a chance to escape by rolling away.

5809.text: It absorbs the iron it finds in the rock while clinging to the ceiling. It shoots spikes when in danger.

5810.text: It defends itself by launching spikes, but its aim isn’t very good at first. Only after a lot of practice will it improve.

5811.text: Mossy caves are their preferred dwellings. Enzymes contained in mosses help Ferroseed’s spikes grow big and strong.

5812.text: It fights by swinging around its three spiky feelers. A hit from these steel spikes can reduce a boulder to rubble.

5813.text: By swinging around its three spiky feelers and shooting spikes, it can obliterate an opponent.

5814.text: They attach themselves to cave ceilings, firing steel spikes at targets passing beneath them.

5815.text: This Pokémon scrapes its spikes across rocks, and then uses the tips of its feelers to absorb the nutrients it finds within the stone.

5816.text: Its spikes are harder than steel. This Pokémon crawls across rock walls by stabbing the spikes on its feelers into the stone.

5817.text: Two bodies comprise a fixed pair. They spin around each other to generate energy.

5818.text: Interlocking two bodies and spinning around generates the energy they need to live.

5819.text: The two minigears that mesh together are predetermined. Each will rebound from other minigears without meshing.

5820.text: The two minigears that compose this Pokémon are closer than twins. They mesh well only with each other.

5821.text: It’s suspected that Klink were the inspiration behind ancient people’s invention of the first gears.

5822.text: Spinning minigears are rotated at high speed and repeatedly fired away. It is dangerous if the gears don’t return.

5823.text: By changing the direction in which it rotates, it communicates its feelings to others. When angry, it rotates faster.

5824.text: A minigear and big gear comprise its body. If the minigear it launches at a foe doesn’t return, it will die.

5825.text: When Klang goes all out, the minigear links up perfectly with the outer part of the big gear, and this Pokémon’s rotation speed increases sharply.

5826.text: Many companies in the Galar region choose Klang as their logo. This Pokémon is considered the symbol of industrial technology.

5827.text: The minigear spins at high speed. Then the energy from the red core charges the minigear to make it ready to fire.

5828.text: The gear with the red core is rotated at high speed for a rapid energy charge.

5829.text: Its red core functions as an energy tank. It fires the charged energy through its spikes into an area.

5830.text: From its spikes, it launches powerful blasts of electricity. Its red core contains an enormous amount of energy.

5831.text: The three gears that compose this Pokémon spin at high speed. Its new spiked gear isn’t a living creature.

5832.text: These Pokémon move in schools. They have an electricity-generating organ, so they discharge electricity if in danger.

5833.text: While one alone doesn’t have much power, a chain of many Tynamo can be as powerful as lightning.

5834.text: One alone can emit only a trickle of electricity, so a group of them gathers to unleash a powerful electric shock.

5835.text: They coil around foes and shock them with electricity-generating organs that seem simply to be circular patterns.

5836.text: It wraps itself around its prey and paralyzes it with electricity from the round spots on its sides. Then it chomps.

5837.text: These Pokémon have a big appetite. When they spot their prey, they attack it and paralyze it with electricity.

5838.text: It latches on to prey with its sucker mouth, sinking in its fangs and shocking the prey with powerful electricity.

5839.text: With their sucker mouths, they suck in prey. Then they use their fangs to shock the prey with electricity.

5840.text: They crawl out of the ocean using their arms. They will attack prey on shore and immediately drag it into the ocean.

5841.text: This Pokémon had never been seen until it appeared from far in the desert 50 years ago.

5842.text: It uses its strong psychic power to squeeze its opponent’s brain, causing unendurable headaches.

5843.text: Rumors of its origin are linked to a UFO crash site in the desert 50 years ago.

5844.text: It controls tremendous psychic power. Most reports of alien sightings are actually just people mistaking Elgyem for an alien.

5845.text: This Pokémon is shrouded in mystery. It’s said to have appeared from a UFO that fell from the sky about 50 years ago.

5846.text: If this Pokémon stands near a TV, strange scenery will appear on the screen. That scenery is said to be from its home.

5847.text: This Pokémon was discovered about 50 years ago. Its highly developed brain enables it to exert its psychic powers.

5848.text: It can manipulate an opponent’s memory. Apparently, it communicates by flashing its three different-colored fingers.

5849.text: Apparently, it communicates by flashing its three fingers, but those patterns haven’t been decoded.

5850.text: It uses psychic power to control an opponent’s brain and tamper with its memories.

5851.text: With its psychic powers, it rewrites its opponents’ memories. You, too, may have already had your memories rewritten.

5852.text: It has strong psychic powers. Using its fingers that flash three different colors, it controls its opponents and rewrites their memories.

5853.text: Whenever a Beheeyem visits a farm, a Dubwool mysteriously disappears.

5854.text: Sometimes found drifting above wheat fields, this Pokémon can control the memories of its opponents.

5855.text: Its flame is usually out, but it starts shining when it absorbs life force from people or Pokémon.

5856.text: While shining a light and pretending to be a guide, it leeches off the life force of any who follow it.

5857.text: Litwick shines a light that absorbs the life energy of people and Pokémon, which becomes the fuel that it burns.

5858.text: The flame on its head keeps its body slightly warm. This Pokémon takes lost children by the hand to guide them to the spirit world.

5859.text: The younger the life this Pokémon absorbs, the brighter and eerier the flame on its head burns.

5860.text: This ominous Pokémon is feared. Through cities it wanders, searching for the spirits of the fallen.

5861.text: The spirits it absorbs fuel its baleful fire. It hangs around hospitals waiting for people to pass on.

5862.text: It arrives near the moment of death and steals spirit from the body.

5863.text: This Pokémon appears just before someone passes away, so it’s feared as an emissary of death.

5864.text: It lurks in cities, pretending to be a lamp. Once it finds someone whose death is near, it will trail quietly after them.

5865.text: It absorbs a spirit, which it then burns. By waving the flames on its arms, it puts its foes into a hypnotic trance.

5866.text: Being consumed in Chandelure’s flame burns up the spirit, leaving the body behind.

5867.text: The spirits burned up in its ominous flame lose their way and wander this world forever.

5868.text: This Pokémon haunts dilapidated mansions. It sways its arms to hypnotize opponents with the ominous dancing of its flames.

5869.text: In homes illuminated by Chandelure instead of lights, funerals were a constant occurrence— or so it’s said.

5870.text: Its large tusks have a tendency to break, but each time they grow back, they grow in harder and sturdier.

5871.text: They use their tusks to crush the berries they eat. Repeated regrowth makes their tusks strong and sharp.

5872.text: They mark their territory by leaving gashes in trees with their tusks. If a tusk breaks, a new one grows in quickly.

5873.text: These Pokémon nest in the ground and use their tusks to crush hard berries. Crushing berries is also how they test each other’s strength.

5874.text: They play with each other by knocking their large tusks together. Their tusks break sometimes, but they grow back so quickly that it isn’t a concern.

5875.text: Their tusks can shatter rocks. Territory battles between Fraxure can be intensely violent.

5876.text: A broken tusk will not grow back, so it diligently sharpens its tusks on river rocks after the end of a battle.

5877.text: After battle, this Pokémon carefully sharpens its tusks on river rocks. It needs to take care of its tusks—if one breaks, it will never grow back.

5878.text: Its skin is as hard as a suit of armor. Fraxure’s favorite strategy is to tackle its opponents, stabbing them with its tusks at the same time.

5879.text: Its tusks are incredibly destructive. They can easily slice through a thick, sturdy steel column every time.

5880.text: They are kind but can be relentless when defending territory. They challenge foes with tusks that can cut steel.

5881.text: Their sturdy tusks will stay sharp even if used to cut steel beams. These Pokémon are covered in hard armor.

5882.text: Its resilient tusks are its pride and joy. It licks up dirt to take in the minerals it needs to keep its tusks in top condition.

5883.text: While usually kindhearted, it can be terrifying if angered. Tusks that can slice through steel beams are how Haxorus deals with its adversaries.

5884.text: When it is not feeling well, its mucus gets watery and the power of its Ice-type moves decreases.

5885.text: Its nose is always running. It sniffs the snot back up because the mucus provides the raw material for its moves.

5886.text: Their snot is a barometer of health. When healthy, their snot is sticky and the power of their ice moves increases.

5887.text: When this Pokémon is in good health, its snot becomes thicker and stickier. It will smear its snot on anyone it doesn’t like.

5888.text: It sniffles before performing a move, using its frosty snot to provide an icy element to any move that needs it.

5889.text: It can make its breath freeze at will. Very able in the water, it swims around in northern seas and catches prey.

5890.text: They love the cold seas of the north. They create pathways across the ocean waters by freezing their own breath.

5891.text: It freezes its breath to create fangs and claws of ice to fight with. Cold northern areas are its habitat.

5892.text: It swims through frigid seas, searching for prey. From its frozen breath, it forms icy fangs that are harder than steel.

5893.text: It swims energetically through frigid seas. When it gets tired, it freezes the seawater with its breath so it can rest on the ice.

5894.text: When its body temperature goes up, it turns into steam and vanishes. When its temperature lowers, it returns to ice.

5895.text: They are born in snow clouds. They use chains made of ice crystals to capture prey.

5896.text: They are composed of ice crystals. They capture prey with chains of ice, freezing the prey at -148 degrees Fahrenheit.

5897.text: With its icy chains, Cryogonal freezes those it encounters. It then takes its victims away to somewhere unknown.

5898.text: When the weather gets hot, these Pokémon turn into water vapor. Cryogonal are almost never seen during summer.

5899.text: When attacked, it defends itself by closing the lid of its shell. It can spit a sticky, poisonous liquid.

5900.text: When it and Karrablast are together, and both receive electrical stimulation, they both evolve.

5901.text: It evolves when bathed in an electric-like energy along with Karrablast. The reason is still unknown.

5902.text: When attacked, it tightly shuts the lid of its shell. This reaction fails to protect it from Karrablast, however, because they can still get into the shell.

5903.text: It has a strange physiology that responds to electricity. When together with Karrablast, Shelmet evolves for some reason.

5904.text: When its body dries out, it weakens. So it wraps a membrane around itself for protection while it spits poison.

5905.text: Having removed its heavy shell, it becomes very light and can fight with ninja-like movements.

5906.text: When its body dries out, it weakens. So, to prevent dehydration, it wraps itself in many layers of thin membrane.

5907.text: It moves with blinding speed and lobs poison at foes. Featuring Accelgor as a main character is a surefire way to make a movie or comic popular.

5908.text: Discarding its shell made it nimble. To keep itself from dehydrating, it wraps its body in bands of membrane.

5909.text: When its opponent can’t be paralyzed, it contorts itself with unexpected speed and flops away.

5910.text: Its skin is very hard, so it is unhurt even if stepped on by sumo wrestlers. It smiles when transmitting electricity.

5911.text: It conceals itself in the mud of the seashore. Then it waits. When prey touch it, it delivers a jolt of electricity.

5912.text: Thanks to bacteria that lived in the mud flats with it, this Pokémon developed the organs it uses to generate electricity.

5913.text: For some reason, this Pokémon smiles slightly when it emits a strong electric current from the yellow markings on its body.

5914.text: They have mastered elegant combos. As they concentrate, their battle moves become swifter and more precise.

5915.text: It takes pride in the speed at which it can use moves. What it loses in power, it makes up for in quantity.

5916.text: In fights, they dominate with onslaughts of flowing, continuous attacks. With their sharp claws, they cut enemies.

5917.text: They can often be seen in packs in the morning, slowly moving their bodies through a series of poses.

5918.text: They seclude themselves in the mountains and devote themselves to training. The form of their kicks and chops differs from pack to pack.

5919.text: In one minute, a well-trained Mienfoo can chop with its arms more than 100 times.

5920.text: Though small, Mienfoo’s temperament is fierce. Any creature that approaches Mienfoo carelessly will be greeted with a flurry of graceful attacks.

5921.text: They use the long fur on their arms as a whip to strike their opponents.

5922.text: It wields the fur on its arms like a whip. Its arm attacks come with such rapidity that they cannot even be seen.

5923.text: Using the long fur on its arms like whips, it launches into combo attacks that, once started, no one can stop.

5924.text: It overwhelms its opponents with continuous attacks and then slowly stores up power before delivering the finishing blow.

5925.text: When Mienshao lets out a bizarre wail, you’re in danger. A flurry of kicks and chops too fast to see is about to be unleashed!

5926.text: When Mienshao comes across a truly challenging opponent, it will lighten itself by biting off the fur on its arms.

5927.text: Delivered at blinding speeds, kicks from this Pokémon can shatter massive boulders into tiny pieces.

5928.text: It runs through the narrow tunnels formed by Excadrill and Onix. It uses its sharp claws to catch prey.

5929.text: It races through narrow caves, using its sharp claws to catch prey. The skin on its face is harder than a rock.

5930.text: It warms its body by absorbing sunlight with its wings. When its body temperature falls, it can no longer move.

5931.text: The red skin on its face is harder than rock. In narrow caves, it squares off against its enemies and charges face-first right into them.

5932.text: It infiltrates tunnels that Pokémon like Diglett and Dugtrio have dug and quietly waits for prey to pass through.

5933.text: Druddigon lives in caves, but it never skips sunbathing—it won’t be able to move if its body gets too cold.

5934.text: Druddigon are vicious and cunning. They take up residence in nests dug out by other Pokémon, treating the stolen nests as their own lairs.

5935.text: These Pokémon are thought to have been created by the science of an ancient and mysterious civilization.

5936.text: The energy that burns inside it enables it to move, but no one has yet been able to identify this energy.

5937.text: Ancient science fashioned this Pokémon from clay. It’s been active for thousands of years.

5938.text: Its movements are powered by a mysterious energy. It has continued to move since ancient times, so its power may soon run out.

5939.text: Although ancient people apparently built it by working with clay, the source of its energy is unclear.

5940.text: They were sculpted from clay in ancient times. No one knows why, but some of them are driven to continually line up boulders.

5941.text: This Pokémon was created from clay. It received orders from its master many thousands of years ago, and it still follows those orders to this day.

5942.text: Golurk were created to protect people and Pokémon. They run on a mysterious energy.

5943.text: It is said that Golurk were ordered to protect people and Pokémon by the ancient people who made them.

5944.text: It flies across the sky at Mach speeds. Removing the seal on its chest makes its internal energy go out of control.

5945.text: Some say that ancient people invented Golurk to serve as a laborer. It follows its master’s orders faithfully.

5946.text: When the seal on its chest is removed, it rages indiscriminately, turning the whole town around it into a mountain of rubble.

5947.text: Artillery platforms built into the walls of ancient castles served as perches from which Golurk could fire energy beams.

5948.text: There’s a theory that inside Golurk is a perpetual motion machine that produces limitless energy, but this belief hasn’t been proven.

5949.text: They fight at Bisharp’s command. They cling to their prey and inflict damage by sinking their blades into it.

5950.text: Blades comprise this Pokémon’s entire body. If battling dulls the blades, it sharpens them on stones by the river.

5951.text: Ignoring their injuries, groups attack by sinking the blades that cover their bodies into their prey.

5952.text: After shredding its prey, it sharpens its blades on a stone by the river. Each Pawniard has its own favorite sharpening stone.

5953.text: It follows Bisharp’s orders to a tee when it attacks enemies. After slashing an opponent, Pawniard clangs both of its blades together.

5954.text: It uses river stones to maintain the cutting edges of the blades covering its body. These sharpened blades allow it to bring down opponents.

5955.text: A pack of these Pokémon forms to serve a Bisharp boss. Each Pawniard trains diligently, dreaming of one day taking the lead.

5956.text: It leads a group of Pawniard. It battles to become the boss, but will be driven from the group if it loses.

5957.text: This pitiless Pokémon commands a group of Pawniard to hound prey into immobility. It then moves in to finish the prey off.

5958.text: Bisharp pursues prey in the company of a large group of Pawniard. Then Bisharp finishes off the prey.

5959.text: No matter how strong the Bisharp, it’s said that if the blade on its head is chipped, it will retire from its position as the boss.

5960.text: It leads a group of Pawniard. Bisharp doesn’t even change its expression when it deals the finishing blow to an opponent.

5961.text: It’s accompanied by a large retinue of Pawniard. Bisharp keeps a keen eye on its minions, ensuring none of them even think of double-crossing it.

5962.text: Violent conflicts erupt between Bisharp and Fraxure over places where sharpening stones can be found.

5963.text: They are known to charge so wildly that if a train were to enter their territory, they would send it flying.

5964.text: They charge wildly and headbutt everything. Their headbutts have enough destructive force to derail a train.

5965.text: Their fluffy fur absorbs damage, even if they strike foes with a fierce headbutt.

5966.text: These Pokémon can crush a car with no more than a headbutt. Bouffalant with more hair on their heads hold higher positions within the herd.

5967.text: These Pokémon live in herds of about 20 individuals. Bouffalant that betray the herd will lose the hair on their heads for some reason.

5968.text: It stands up to massive opponents, not out of courage, but out of recklessness. But that is how it gets stronger.

5969.text: They crush berries with their talons. They bravely stand up to any opponent, no matter how strong it is.

5970.text: They will challenge anything, even strong opponents, without fear. Their frequent fights help them become stronger.

5971.text: They pick fights indiscriminately. They grow stronger and more powerful each time they faint or are injured.

5972.text: With its sharp claws, this Pokémon pierces its prey, and then it pecks at them. Although it also consumes berries, it’s a carnivore at heart.

5973.text: With its powerful legs and sturdy claws, it can crack even the hard shells of Shellder and pluck out their insides.

5974.text: Known as a natural-born warrior, soon after its hatching, it will challenge its parent to a fight in order to gain their acceptance.

5975.text: If it spies a strong Pokémon, Rufflet can’t resist challenging it to a battle. But if Rufflet loses, it starts bawling.

5976.text: A combative Pokémon, it’s ready to pick a fight with anyone. It has talons that can crush hard berries.

5977.text: Its chick-like looks belie its hotheadedness. It challenges its parents at every opportunity, desperate to prove its strength.

5978.text: The more scars they have, the more respect these brave soldiers of the sky  get from their peers.

5979.text: For the sake of its friends, this brave warrior of the sky will not stop battling, even if injured.

5980.text: They fight for their friends without any thought about danger to themselves. One can carry a car while flying.

5981.text: With its brave disposition, it fears nothing—not even death. Ancient Alolan people respected it, referring to it as “the hero of the sky.”

5982.text: It’s thought that people disturbed their habitats in the past, so Braviary banded together to fight back.

5983.text: The more scars it has on its front, the more heroic it’s considered to be. Those with many scars on their back are mocked by the flock.

5984.text: Known as “the hero of the skies,” this Pokémon is so proud and so brave that it will never retreat, even when it’s injured.

5985.text: Known for its bravery and pride, this majestic Pokémon is often seen as a motif for various kinds of emblems.

5986.text: Because this Pokémon is hotheaded and belligerent, it’s Corviknight that’s taken the role of transportation in Galar.

5987.text: Screaming a bloodcurdling battle cry, this huge and ferocious bird Pokémon goes out on the hunt. It blasts lakes with shock waves, then scoops up any prey that float to the water's surface.

5988.text: They tend to guard their posteriors with suitable bones they have found. They pursue weak Pokémon.

5989.text: Its wings are too tiny to allow it to fly. As the time approaches for it to evolve, it discards the bones it was wearing.

5990.text: Their wings are too tiny to allow them to fly. They guard their posteriors with bones that were gathered by Mandibuzz.

5991.text: It protects its plump posterior with the bones of prey it has consumed. As it grows, it  replaces the bones.

5992.text: It can’t fly yet and must wait until its wings have developed more. Since it’s still at a playful age, it hops around friskily.

5993.text: Mandibuzz gives it the bones it wears. Vullaby’s wings are short, so it can’t fly yet, but it jumps around, dreaming of wide open skies.

5994.text: Its healthy appetite leads to visible growth spurts. It often has to replace the bones it wears as its size increases.

5995.text: It wears a bone to protect its rear. It often squabbles with others of its kind over particularly comfy bones.

5996.text: Vullaby grow quickly. Bones that have gotten too small for older Vullaby to wear often get passed down to younger ones in the nest.

5997.text: It makes a nest out of bones it finds. It grabs weakened prey in its talons and hauls it to its nest of bones.

5998.text: They fly in circles around the sky. When they spot prey, they attack and carry it back to their nest with ease.

5999.text: Watching from the sky, they swoop to strike weakened Pokémon on the ground. They decorate themselves with bones.

6000.text: They adorn themselves beautifully with bones. This is supposedly an effort to attract males, but no male Mandibuzz have ever been found.

6001.text: It circles in the sky, keeping a keen eye out for Pokémon in a weakened state. Its choicest food is Cubone.

6002.text: It skillfully arranges the bones of its prey to construct its nest. Most of the bones are Cubone.

6003.text: It’s always searching for food for Vullaby. When it finds a weak Pokémon, Mandibuzz swoops it right off to its nest.

6004.text: Although it’s a bit of a ruffian, this Pokémon will take lost Vullaby under its wing and care for them till they’re ready to leave the nest.

6005.text: They adorn themselves with bones. There seem to be fashion trends among them, as different bones come into and fall out of popularity.

6006.text: It breathes through a hole in its tail while it burns with an internal fire. Durant is its prey.

6007.text: Using their very hot, flame-covered tongues, they burn through Durant’s steel bodies and consume their insides.

6008.text: It draws in air through its tail, transforms it into fire, and uses it like a tongue. It melts Durant and eats them.

6009.text: There’s a hole in its tail that allows it to draw in the air it needs to keep its fire burning. If the hole gets blocked, this Pokémon will fall ill.

6010.text: A flame serves as its tongue, melting through the hard shell of Durant so that Heatmor can devour their insides.

6011.text: Durant dig nests in mountains. They build their complicated, interconnected tunnels into mazes.

6012.text: Individuals each play different roles in driving Heatmor, their natural predator, away from their colony.

6013.text: They attack in groups, covering themselves in steel armor to protect themselves from Heatmor.

6014.text: They lay their eggs deep inside their nests. When attacked by Heatmor, they retaliate using their massive mandibles.

6015.text: With their large mandibles, these Pokémon can crunch their way through rock. They work together to protect their eggs from Sandaconda.

6016.text: It tends to bite everything, and it is not a picky eater. Approaching it carelessly is dangerous.

6017.text: They cannot see, so they tackle and bite to learn about their surroundings. Their bodies are covered in wounds.

6018.text: Lacking sight, it’s unaware of its surroundings, so it bumps into things and eats anything that moves.

6019.text: When it encounters something, its first urge is usually to bite it. If it likes what it tastes, it will commit the associated scent to memory.

6020.text: Because it can’t see, this Pokémon is constantly biting at everything it touches, trying to keep track of its surroundings.

6021.text: Since their two heads do not get along and compete with each other for food, they always eat too much.

6022.text: After it has eaten up all the food in its territory, it moves to another area. Its two heads do not get along.

6023.text: The two heads do not get along. Whichever head eats more than the other gets to be the leader.

6024.text: While hunting for prey, Zweilous wanders its territory, its two heads often bickering over which way to go.

6025.text: Their two heads will fight each other over a single piece of food. Zweilous are covered in scars even without battling others.

6026.text: This brutal Pokémon travels the skies on its six wings. Anything that moves seems like a foe to it, triggering its attack.

6027.text: The heads on their arms do not have brains. They use all three heads to consume and destroy everything.

6028.text: It responds to movement by attacking. This scary, three-headed Pokémon devours everything in its path!

6029.text: There are a slew of stories about villages that were destroyed by Hydreigon. It bites anything that moves.

6030.text: The three heads take turns sinking their teeth into the opponent. Their attacks won’t slow until their target goes down.

6031.text: This Pokémon was believed to have been born from the sun. When it evolves, its entire body is engulfed in flames.

6032.text: Said to have been born from the sun, it spews fire from its horns and encases itself in a cocoon of fire when it evolves.

6033.text: The base of volcanoes is where they make their homes. They shoot fire from their five horns to repel attacking enemies.

6034.text: When battling opponents, it sprays fire from its five horns. The max temperature of the flames can reach nearly 5,500 degrees Fahrenheit.

6035.text: It protects itself with flame. Long years ago, people believed Larvesta had a nest on the sun.

6036.text: The people of ancient times believed that Larvesta fell from the sun.

6037.text: Larvesta’s body is warm all over. It spouts fire from the tips of its horns to intimidate predators and scare prey.

6038.text: Thought to be an embodiment of the sun, it appeared during a bitterly cold winter and saved Pokémon from freezing.

6039.text: A sea of fire engulfs the surroundings of their battles, since they use their six wings to scatter their ember scales.

6040.text: When volcanic ash darkened the atmosphere, it is said that Volcarona’s fire provided a replacement for the sun.

6041.text: As it flies, it scatters its flaming scales. It was feared by ancient people, who referred to it as “the rage of the sun.”

6042.text: According to legends, it was hatched from a flaming cocoon to save people and Pokémon that were suffering from the cold.

6043.text: Volcarona scatters burning scales. Some say it does this to start fires. Others say it’s trying to rescue those that suffer in the cold.

6044.text: This Pokémon emerges from a cocoon formed of raging flames. Ancient murals depict Volcarona as a deity of fire.

6045.text: This legendary Pokémon battled against humans to protect Pokémon. Its personality is calm and composed.

6046.text: It has a body and heart of steel. Its glare is sufficient to make even an unruly Pokémon obey it.

6047.text: It has a body and heart of steel. It worked with its allies to punish people when they hurt Pokémon.

6048.text: This Pokémon appears in a legend alongside Terrakion and Virizion, fighting against humans in defense of the Unova region’s Pokémon.

6049.text: From the moment it’s born, this Pokémon radiates the air of a leader. Its presence will calm even vicious foes.

6050.text: This Pokémon came to the defense of Pokémon that had lost their homes in a war among humans.

6051.text: Its charge is strong enough to break through a giant castle wall in one blow. This Pokémon is spoken of in legends.

6052.text: Spoken of in legend, this Pokémon used its phenomenal power to destroy a castle in its effort to protect Pokémon.

6053.text: It has phenomenal power. It will mercilessly crush anyone or anything that bullies small Pokémon.

6054.text: In Unovan legend, Terrakion battled against humans in an effort to protect other Pokémon.

6055.text: This Pokémon fought humans in order to protect its friends. Legends about it continue to be passed down.

6056.text: Its head sprouts horns as sharp as blades. Using whirlwind-like movements, it confounds and swiftly cuts opponents.

6057.text: Legends say this Pokémon confounded opponents with its swift movements.

6058.text: A legend tells of this Pokémon working together with Cobalion and Terrakion to protect the Pokémon of the Unova region.

6059.text: It darts around opponents with a flurry of quick movements, slicing them up with its horns.

6060.text: In every direction it flies, creating winds so powerful, they blow everything away.

6061.text: The lower half of its body is wrapped in a cloud of energy. It zooms through the sky at 200 mph.

6062.text: Tornadus expels massive energy from its tail, causing severe storms. Its power is great enough to blow houses away.

6063.text: This storm-stirring Pokémon is said to cause the seasons to turn by whipping up the air. I suspect its humanlike form to be a false one.

6064.text: Countless charred remains mar the landscape of places through which Thundurus has passed.

6065.text: The spikes on its tail discharge immense bolts of lightning. It flies around the Unova region firing off lightning bolts.

6066.text: As it flies around, it shoots lightning all over the place and causes forest fires. It is therefore disliked.

6067.text: They say this wielder of electricity has waged war with its nemesis, Tornadus, since time immemorial. The lightning bolts it hurls pierce the very earth and enrich the soil.

6068.text: This Pokémon appears in legends. It sends flames into the air from its tail, burning up everything around it.

6069.text: This legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with fire. It helps those who want to build a world of truth.

6070.text: When Reshiram’s tail flares, the heat energy moves the atmosphere and changes the world’s weather.

6071.text: Flames spew from its tail as it flies through the sky like a jet airplane. It’s said that this Pokémon will scorch the world.

6072.text: According to myth, if people ignore truth and let themselves become consumed by greed, Reshiram will arrive to burn their kingdoms down.

6073.text: This Pokémon appears in legends. In its tail, it has a giant generator that creates electricity.

6074.text: This legendary Pokémon can scorch the world with lightning. It assists those who want to build an ideal world.

6075.text: Concealing itself in lightning clouds, it flies throughout the Unova region. It creates electricity in its tail.

6076.text: When the interior part of its tail spins like a motor, Zekrom can generate many bolts of lightning to blast its surroundings.

6077.text: Mythology tells us that if people lose the righteousness in their hearts, their kingdoms will be razed by Zekrom’s lightning.

6078.text: The energy that comes pouring from its tail increases the nutrition in the soil, making crops grow to great size.

6079.text: Lands visited by Landorus grant such bountiful crops that it has been hailed as “The Guardian of the Fields.”

6080.text: From the forces of lightning and wind, it creates energy to give nutrients to the soil and make the land abundant.

6081.text: When the incarnations of wind and of lightning clash, Landorus arrives to quell the conflict. After the tempests and thunderbolts abate, the land is sure to be blessed with bountiful harvests.

6082.text: It can produce ultracold air. Its body is frozen.

6083.text: This legendary ice Pokémon waits for a hero to fill in the missing parts of its body with truth or ideals.

6084.text: It generates a powerful, freezing energy inside itself, but its body became frozen when the energy leaked out.

6085.text: Dwelling within it is a power even greater than that of Reshiram or Zekrom, but the extreme cold keeps that power bound.

6086.text: It appears that this Pokémon uses its powers over ice to freeze its own body in order to stabilize its cellular structure.

6087.text: By blasting water from its hooves, it can glide across water. It excels at using leg moves while battling.

6088.text: It crosses the world, running over the surfaces of oceans and rivers. It appears at scenic waterfronts.

6089.text: When it is resolute, its body fills with power and it becomes swifter. Its jumps are then too fast to follow.

6090.text: Cobalion, Terrakion, and Virizion taught this Pokémon how to fight. It dashes across the world, seeking more opportunities to further its training.

6091.text: They say that Keldeo must survive harsh battles and fully develop the horn on its forehead before this Pokémon’s true power will awaken.

6092.text: Many famous songs have been inspired by the melodies that Meloetta plays.

6093.text: The melodies sung by Meloetta have the power to make Pokémon that hear them happy or sad.

6094.text: Its melodies are sung with a special vocalization method that can control the feelings of those who hear it.

6095.text: Over 300 million years ago, it was feared as the strongest of hunters. It has been modified by Team Plasma.

6096.text: This ancient bug Pokémon was altered by Team Plasma. They upgraded the cannon on its back.

6097.text: This Pokémon existed 300 million years ago. Team Plasma altered it and attached a cannon to its back.

6098.text: The quills on its head are usually soft. When it flexes them, the points become so hard and sharp that they can pierce rock.

6099.text: Such a thick shell of wood covers its head and back that even a direct hit from a truck wouldn’t faze it.

6100.text: It relies on its sturdy shell to deflect predators’ attacks. It counterattacks with its sharp quills.

6101.text: They strengthen their lower bodies by running into one another. They are very kind and won’t start fights.

6102.text: Its Tackle is forceful enough to flip a 50-ton tank. It shields its allies from danger with its own body.

6103.text: When it takes a defensive posture with its fists guarding its face, it could withstand a bomb blast.

6104.text: Eating a twig fills it with energy, and its roomy ears give vent to air hotter than 390 degrees Fahrenheit.

6105.text: As it walks, it munches on a twig in place of a snack. It intimidates opponents by puffing hot air out of its ears.

6106.text: It has a twig stuck in its tail. With friction from its tail fur, it sets the twig on fire and launches into battle.

6107.text: When the twig is plucked from its tail, friction sets the twig alight. The flame is used to send signals to its allies.

6108.text: It gazes into the flame at the tip of its branch to achieve a focused state, which allows it to see into the future.

6109.text: Using psychic power, it generates a fiery vortex of 5,400 degrees Fahrenheit, incinerating foes swept into this whirl of flame.

6110.text: It secretes flexible bubbles from its chest and back. The bubbles reduce the damage it would otherwise take when attacked.

6111.text: It protects its skin by covering its body in delicate bubbles. Beneath its happy-go-lucky air, it keeps a watchful eye on its surroundings.

6112.text: It can throw bubble-covered pebbles with precise control, hitting empty cans up to a hundred feet away.

6113.text: Its swiftness is unparalleled. It can scale a tower of more than 2,000 feet in a minute’s time.

6114.text: It creates throwing stars out of compressed water. When it spins them and throws them at high speed, these stars can split metal in two.

6115.text: It appears and vanishes with a ninja’s grace. It toys with its enemies using swift movements, while slicing them with throwing stars of sharpest water.

6116.text: They use their large ears to dig burrows. They will dig the whole night through.

6117.text: It has ears like shovels. Digging holes strengthens its ears so much that they can sever thick roots effortlessly.

6118.text: It excels at digging holes. Using its ears, it can dig a nest 33 feet deep in one night.

6119.text: It’s very sensitive to danger. The sound of Corviknight’s flapping will have Bunnelby digging a hole to hide underground in moments.

6120.text: With their powerful ears, they can heft boulders of a ton or more with ease. They can be a big help at construction sites.

6121.text: As powerful as an excavator, its ears can reduce dense bedrock to rubble. When it’s finished digging, it lounges lazily.

6122.text: With power equal to an excavator, it can dig through dense bedrock. It’s a huge help during tunnel construction.

6123.text: The fur on its belly retains heat exceptionally well. People used to make heavy winter clothing from fur shed by this Pokémon.

6124.text: These friendly Pokémon send signals to one another with beautiful chirps and tail-feather movements.

6125.text: Despite the beauty of its lilting voice, it’s merciless to intruders that enter its territory.

6126.text: This amiable Pokémon is easy to train. But when battle is joined, it shows its ferocious side.

6127.text: When it’s excited, its temperature can double, spiking hormone production in its body.

6128.text: While it’s an amiable Pokémon, if you touch it unexpectedly, it will heat up its body in an instant, and you’ll be burned.

6129.text: Its body is always warm. Trainers who live in cold areas apparently sleep with it in their bed.

6130.text: Its melodious cries are actually warnings. Fletchling will mercilessly peck at anything that enters its territory.

6131.text: When this Pokémon gets excited, its body temperature increases sharply. If you touch a Fletchling with bare hands, you might get burned.

6132.text: From its beak, it expels embers that set the tall grass on fire. Then it pounces on the bewildered prey that pop out of the grass.

6133.text: The hotter the flame sac on its belly, the faster it can fly, but it takes some time to get the fire going.

6134.text: From its beak, it fires embers at its prey. Once it has caught them, it grills them at high heat before feasting upon them.

6135.text: It will not tolerate other Fletchinder entering its territory, which has a radius of several miles.

6136.text: It scatters embers in the tall grass. Then bug Pokémon, frightened by the flames, come flying out, and Fletchinder gobbles them up.

6137.text: Its speed right after takeoff already puts it in the top speed class of all bird Pokémon.

6138.text: Fletchinder launches embers into the den of its prey. When the prey comes leaping out, Fletchinder’s sharp talons finish it off.

6139.text: Fletchinder are exceedingly territorial and aggressive. These Pokémon fight among themselves over feeding grounds.

6140.text: In the fever of an exciting battle, it showers embers from the gaps between its feathers and takes to the air.

6141.text: When attacking prey, it can reach speeds of up to 310 mph. It finishes its prey off with a colossal kick.

6142.text: Its favorite foods are Wingull and Pikipek. It attacks with a powerful kick and grasps them firmly in its talons.

6143.text: It zooms directly at its prey at flight speeds of close to 310 mph, while fiery embers scatter from gaps in its feathers.

6144.text: Its tough wings don’t allow fire to pass through them. A long time ago, firefighters’ outfits were made from Talonflame wings.

6145.text: Bird Pokémon make up most of its diet. It approaches at high speeds and smacks them down to the ground with its powerful kick.

6146.text: Talonflame mainly preys upon other bird Pokémon. To intimidate opponents, it sends embers spewing from gaps between its feathers.

6147.text: Talonflame dives toward prey at speeds of up to 310 mph and assaults them with powerful kicks, giving the prey no chance to escape.

6148.text: When under attack from bird Pokémon, it spews a poisonous black powder that causes paralysis on contact.

6149.text: The powder that covers its body regulates its temperature, so it can live in any region or climate.

6150.text: It lives hidden within thicket shadows. When predators attack, it quickly bristles the fur covering its body in an effort to threaten them.

6151.text: The beaks of bird Pokémon can’t begin to scratch its stalwart body. To defend itself, it spews powder.

6152.text: Vivillon with many different patterns are found all over the world. These patterns are affected by the climate of their habitat.

6153.text: The patterns on this Pokémon’s wings depend on the climate and topography of its habitat. It scatters colorful scales.

6154.text: The stronger the opponent it faces, the more heat surges from its mane and the more power flows through its body.

6155.text: They set off on their own from their pride and live by themselves to become stronger. These hot-blooded Pokémon are quick to fight.

6156.text: When they’re young, they live with a pride. Once they’re able to hunt prey on their own, they’re kicked out and have to make their own way.

6157.text: This hot-blooded Pokémon is filled with curiosity. When it gets angry or starts fighting, its short mane gets hot.

6158.text: The male with the largest mane of fire is the leader of the pride.

6159.text: With fiery breath of more than 10,000 degrees Fahrenheit, they viciously threaten any challenger. The females protect the pride’s cubs.

6160.text: The males are usually lazy, but when attacked by a strong foe, a male will protect its friends with no regard for its own safety.

6161.text: The temperature of its breath is over 10,000 degrees Fahrenheit, but Pyroar doesn’t use it on its prey. This Pokémon prefers to eat raw meat.

6162.text: It draws out and controls the hidden power of flowers. The flower Flabébé holds is most likely part of its body.

6163.text: When it finds a flower it likes, it dwells on that flower its whole life long. It floats in the wind’s embrace with an untroubled heart.

6164.text: It’s not safe without the power of a flower, but it will keep traveling around until it finds one with the color and shape it wants.

6165.text: Flabébé wears a crown made from pollen it’s collected from its flower. The crown has hidden healing properties.

6166.text: It flutters around fields of flowers and cares for flowers that are starting to wilt. It draws out the hidden power of flowers to battle.

6167.text: When the flowers of a well-tended flower bed bloom, it appears and celebrates with an elegant dance.

6168.text: It raises flowers and uses them as weapons. The more gorgeous the blossom, the more power it contains.

6169.text: It gives its own power to flowers, pouring its heart into caring for them. Floette never forgives anyone who messes up a flower bed.

6170.text: It claims exquisite flower gardens as its territory, and it obtains power from basking in the energy emitted by flowering plants.

6171.text: In times long past, governors of castles would invite Florges to create flower gardens to embellish the castle domains.

6172.text: It controls the flowers it grows. The petal blizzards that Florges triggers are overwhelming in their beauty and power.

6173.text: Its life can span several hundred years. It’s said to devote its entire life to protecting gardens.

6174.text: Thought to be one of the first Pokémon to live in harmony with humans, it has a placid disposition.

6175.text: If it has sunshine and water, it doesn’t need to eat, because it can generate energy from the leaves on its back.

6176.text: It can tell how its Trainer is feeling by subtle shifts in the grip on its horns. This empathic sense lets them run as if one being.

6177.text: They inhabit mountainous regions. The leader of the herd is decided by a battle of clashing horns.

6178.text: It does its best to be taken seriously by its enemies, but its glare is not sufficiently intimidating. Chewing on a leaf is its trademark.

6179.text: It does its level best to glare and pull a scary face, but it can’t help grinning if anyone pats its head.

6180.text: It grows up imitating the behavior of Pangoro, which it looks up to as a leader.

6181.text: There’s no point to the leaf in its mouth, aside from an effort to look cool. It’s mischievous, so it’s not well suited to inexperienced Trainers.

6182.text: It follows Pangoro around like a henchman. When Pancham makes a big mistake, its leaf gets taken away.

6183.text: It’s desperate to intimidate its opponents. Be nice and pretend to be scared if you catch it glaring at you intensely.

6184.text: It chooses a Pangoro as its master and then imitates its master’s actions. This is how it learns to battle and hunt for prey.

6185.text: Wanting to make sure it’s taken seriously, Pancham’s always giving others a glare. But if it’s not focusing, it ends up smiling.

6186.text: Although it possesses a violent temperament, it won’t put up with bullying. It uses the leaf in its mouth to sense the movements of its enemies.

6187.text: It charges ahead and bashes its opponents like a berserker, uncaring about any hits it might take. Its arms are mighty enough to snap a telephone pole.

6188.text: It boasts superb physical strength. Those who wish to become Pangoro’s Trainer have no choice but to converse with their fists.

6189.text: From the slight twitches of its bamboo leaf, it deduces its opponent’s movements. It’s eager to tussle but kindhearted toward its companions.

6190.text: This rowdy Pokémon boasts great physical strength. Many Trainers are also smitten by its lively character.

6191.text: Pangoro is the type to talk with its fists. It doesn’t say much as it pummels opponents with enough force to send a dump truck flying.

6192.text: This Pokémon is quick to anger, and it has no problem using its prodigious strength to get its way. It lives for duels against Obstagoon.

6193.text: Using its leaf, Pangoro can predict the moves of its opponents. It strikes with punches that can turn a dump truck into scrap with just one hit.

6194.text: Trimming its fluffy fur not only makes it more elegant but also increases the swiftness of its movements.

6195.text: Historically, in the Kalos region, these Pokémon were the designated guardians of the king.

6196.text: There was an era when aristocrats would compete to see who could trim their Furfrou’s fur into the most exquisite style.

6197.text: Left alone, its fur will grow longer and longer, but it will only allow someone it trusts to cut it.

6198.text: The organ that emits its intense psychic power is sheltered by its ears to keep power from leaking out.

6199.text: It has enough psychic energy to blast everything within 300 feet of itself, but it has no control over its power.

6200.text: Though Espurr’s expression never changes, behind that blank stare is an intense struggle to contain its devastating psychic power.

6201.text: There’s enough psychic power in Espurr to send a wrestler flying, but because this power can’t be controlled, Espurr finds it troublesome.

6202.text: When in danger, it raises its ears and releases enough psychic power to grind a 10-ton truck into dust.

6203.text: The eyeball patterns on the interior of its ears emit psychic energy. It keeps the patterns tightly covered because that power is too immense.

6204.text: Revealing the eyelike patterns on the insides of its ears will unleash its psychic powers. It normally keeps the patterns hidden, however.

6205.text: The defensive instinct of the males is strong. It’s when they’re protecting themselves or their partners that they unleash their full power.

6206.text: Apparently this Pokémon is born when a departed spirit inhabits a sword. It attaches itself to people and drinks their life force.

6207.text: If anyone dares to grab its hilt, it wraps a blue cloth around that person’s arm and drains that person’s life energy completely.

6208.text: Honedge’s soul once belonged to a person who was killed a long time ago by the sword that makes up Honedge’s body.

6209.text: The blue eye on the sword’s handguard is the true body of Honedge. With its old cloth, it drains people’s lives away.

6210.text: When Honedge evolves, it divides into two swords, which cooperate via telepathy to coordinate attacks and slash their enemies to ribbons.

6211.text: The complex attack patterns of its two swords are unstoppable, even for an opponent greatly accomplished at swordplay.

6212.text: Honedge evolves into twins. The two blades rub together to emit a metallic sound that unnerves opponents.

6213.text: The two swords employ a strategy of rapidly alternating between offense and defense to bring down their prey.

6214.text: Generations of kings were attended by these Pokémon, which used their spectral power to manipulate and control people and Pokémon.

6215.text: Apparently, it can detect the innate qualities of leadership. According to legend, whoever it recognizes is destined to become king.

6216.text: In this defensive stance, Aegislash uses its steel body and a force field of spectral power to reduce the damage of any attack.

6217.text: Its potent spectral powers allow it to manipulate others. It once used its powers to force people and Pokémon to build a kingdom to its liking.

6218.text: It emits a scent that enraptures those who smell it. This fragrance changes depending on what it has eaten.

6219.text: In the past, rather than using perfume, royal ladies carried a Spritzee that would waft a fragrance they liked.

6220.text: A scent pouch within this Pokémon’s body allows it to create various scents. A change in its diet will alter the fragrance it produces.

6221.text: The scent its body gives off enraptures those who smell it. Noble ladies had no shortage of love for Spritzee.

6222.text: It devises various scents, pleasant and unpleasant, and emits scents that its enemies dislike in order to gain an edge in battle.

6223.text: Its scent is so overpowering that, unless a Trainer happens to really enjoy the smell, he or she will have a hard time walking alongside it.

6224.text: The scent that constantly emits from its fur is so powerful that this Pokémon’s companions will eventually lose their sense of smell.

6225.text: The scents Aromatisse can produce range from sweet smells that bolster allies to foul smells that sap an opponent’s will to fight.

6226.text: To entangle its opponents in battle, it extrudes white threads as sweet and sticky as cotton candy.

6227.text: Because it eats nothing but sweets, its fur is as sticky sweet as cotton candy.

6228.text: It eats its own weight in sugar every day. If it doesn’t get enough sugar, it becomes incredibly grumpy.

6229.text: The sweet smell of cotton candy perfumes Swirlix’s fluffy fur. This Pokémon spits out sticky string to tangle up its enemies.

6230.text: It can distinguish the faintest of scents. It puts its sensitive sense of smell to use by helping pastry chefs in their work.

6231.text: Its sense of smell is 100 million times better than a human’s, so even the faintest scent tells it about everything in the area. It’s like it can see with its nose!

6232.text: By taking in a person’s scent, it can sniff out their mental and physical condition. It’s hoped that this skill will have many medical applications.

6233.text: Slurpuff’s fur contains a lot of air, making it soft to the touch and lighter than it looks.

6234.text: Opponents who stare at the flashing of the light-emitting spots on its body become dazed and lose their will to fight.

6235.text: It flashes the light-emitting spots on its body, which drains its opponent’s will to fight. It takes the opportunity to scuttle away and hide.

6236.text: It draws prey near with its blinking lights and then wraps them up in its long tentacles and holds them in place.

6237.text: When exchanging information with others of its kind, it flashes the light-emitting spots on its body in a complex rhythm.

6238.text: It spins while making its luminescent spots flash. These spots allow it to communicate with others by using different patterns of light.

6239.text: By exposing foes to the blinking of its luminescent spots, Inkay demoralizes them, and then it seizes the chance to flee.

6240.text: It wields the most compelling hypnotic powers of any Pokémon, and it forces others to do whatever it wants.

6241.text: It lures its prey close with hypnotic motions, then wraps its tentacles around it before finishing it off with digestive fluids.

6242.text: When it comes to strong hypnosis, there’s an endless number of people who utilize Malamar for their nefarious deeds.

6243.text: It flashes the pattern on its torso to control its prey and draw them in. The edges of its fins are supremely sharp.

6244.text: Gazing at its luminescent spots will quickly induce a hypnotic state, putting the observer under Malamar’s control.

6245.text: It’s said that Malamar’s hypnotic powers played a role in certain history-changing events.

6246.text: Two Binacle live together on one rock. When they fight, one of them will move to a different rock.

6247.text: They stretch and then contract, yanking their rocks along with them in bold hops. They eat seaweed that washes up on the shoreline.

6248.text: After two Binacle find a suitably sized rock, they adhere themselves to it and live together. They cooperate to gather food during high tide.

6249.text: If the two don’t work well together, both their offense and defense fall apart. Without good teamwork, they won’t survive.

6250.text: When they evolve, two Binacle multiply into seven. They fight with the power of seven Binacle.

6251.text: Barbaracle’s legs and hands have minds of their own, and they will move independently. But they usually follow the head’s orders.

6252.text: Seven Binacle come together to form one Barbaracle. The Binacle that serves as the head gives orders to those serving as the limbs.

6253.text: Having an eye on each palm allows it to keep watch in all directions. In a pinch, its limbs start to act on their own to ensure the enemy’s defeat.

6254.text: Camouflaged as rotten kelp, they spray liquid poison on prey that approaches unawares and then finish it off.

6255.text: It looks just like rotten kelp. It hides from foes while storing up power for its evolution.

6256.text: It vanishes into seaweed and remains perfectly still to avoid attacks from large Pokémon. Rotten seaweed is its main food source.

6257.text: It’s not good at swimming, so it clings to the seaweed. In the Alola region, it’s often found near Dhelmise.

6258.text: It drifts in the ocean, blending in with floating seaweed. When other Pokémon come to feast on the seaweed, Skrelp feasts on them instead.

6259.text: Skrelp looks like a piece of rotten seaweed, so it can blend in with seaweed drifting on the ocean and avoid being detected by enemies.

6260.text: Their poison is strong enough to eat through the hull of a tanker, and they spit it indiscriminately at anything that enters their territory.

6261.text: Tales are told of ships that wander into seas where Dragalge live, never to return.

6262.text: This vicious Pokémon sprays a poisonous liquid on opponents that come near. For whatever reason, it gets along really well with Dhelmise.

6263.text: It blends in with seaweed to ambush its prey and then takes them down with a poisonous liquid strong enough to melt metal.

6264.text: Dragalge uses a poisonous liquid capable of corroding metal to send tankers that enter its territory to the bottom of the sea.

6265.text: Dragalge generates dragon energy by sticking the plume on its head out above the ocean’s surface and bathing it in sunlight.

6266.text: They knock down flying prey by firing compressed water from their massive claws like shooting a pistol.
